elements.content: By treating Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with a V-shaped ligand 4,4ʼ-oxydibenzoic acid (H2oba), a dynamic metal-carboxylate framework [Cu2(oba)2(DMF)2]·5.25DMF (MCF-23) was synthesized, which features a wavelike layer with rhombic grids based on the paddle-wheel secondary building units. These layers stack via strong offset π-π stacking of the phenyl groups of oba ligands to give three-dimensional porosity. MCF-23 synthesized by conventional solvothermal methods always contains considerable and intractable impurities. In contrast, a microwave-assisted solvothermal method was proven to be a faster and greener approach to synthesize phase-pure MCF-23 in high yield. More interestingly, larger crystals suitable for single-crystal diffraction could be obtained by the multistep microwave heating mode. A powder X-ray diffraction study of MCF-23 reveals the dynamic structural transformation accompanying the release and reabsorption of the guest molecules. The N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K) gas sorption isotherms of the guest-free phase MCF-23a were measured.
elements.clean_text: By treating Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O with a V-shaped ligand 4,4ʼ-oxydibenzoic acid (H2oba), a dynamic metal-carboxylate framework [Cu2(oba)2(DMF)2]⋅5.25DMF (MCF-23) was synthesized, which features a wavelike layer with rhombic grids based on the paddle-wheel secondary building units. These layers stack via strong offset π-π stacking of the phenyl groups of oba ligands to give three-dimensional porosity. MCF-23 synthesized by conventional solvothermal methods always contains considerable and intractable impurities. In contrast, a microwave-assisted solvothermal method was proven to be a faster and greener approach to synthesize phase-pure MCF-23 in high yield. More interestingly, larger crystals suitable for single-crystal diffraction could be obtained by the multistep microwave heating mode. A powder X-ray diffraction study of MCF-23 reveals the dynamic structural transformation accompanying the release and reabsorption of the guest molecules. The N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K) gas sorption isotherms of the guest-free phase MCF-23a were measured.

elements.content: Contrasted to a conventional solvothermal method presenting impurities, a single-step or multistep microwave heating mode was shown to be a faster and greener approach in high yield and phase purity to construct a metal-carboxylate framework MCF-23 by treating Cu2+ with a V-shaped ligand 4,4ʼ-oxydibenzoic acid.
elements.clean_text: Contrasted to a conventional solvothermal method presenting impurities, a single-step or multistep microwave heating mode was shown to be a faster and greener approach in high yield and phase purity to construct a metal-carboxylate framework MCF-23 by treating Cu2+ with a V-shaped ligand 4,4ʼ-oxydibenzoic acid.

elements.content: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have been enjoying greater and greater prominence worldwide owing to the creation of novel supramolecular architectures and their unique functionalities and potential applications in storage, separation, and heterogeneous catalysis. As a new category of porous materials, PCPs have the advantages of complete order, high porosity, and designable frameworks, in contrast to conventional porous materials. The past two decades have witnessed remarkable progress in the field of PCPs in the rational design, controllable synthesis, and pores modification. Nevertheless, PCPs is still in its infancy of development, exploration of rational design and synthetic approaches are highly demanded. In this context, new approaches such as high-throughput, ionothermal, microwave-assisted, and microwave ionothermal syntheses have been introduced to the synthesis of PCPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have been enjoying greater and greater prominence worldwide owing to the creation of novel supramolecular architectures and their unique functionalities and potential applications in storage, separation, and heterogeneous catalysis. As a new category of porous materials, PCPs have the advantages of complete order, high porosity, and designable frameworks, in contrast to conventional porous materials. The past two decades have witnessed remarkable progress in the field of PCPs in the rational design, controllable synthesis, and pores modification. Nevertheless, PCPs is still in its infancy of development, exploration of rational design and synthetic approaches are highly demanded. In this context, new approaches such as high-throughput, ionothermal, microwave-assisted, and microwave ionothermal syntheses have been introduced to the synthesis of PCPs.

elements.content: In contrast to the conventional heating solvothermal method, which requires a long time (typically half to several days) and high electric power (over a thousand Watts), microwave-assisted heating is a greener approach to synthesize materials in a shorter time (several minutes to hours) and with lower power consumption (hundreds of Watts) as a consequence of directly and uniformly heating the contents. Consequently, it emerges as a feasible approach in organic synthesis, inorganic hybrid materials and for nanoscale particle preparations. One can reasonably expect that microwave-assisted solvothermal synthesis (MASS) is a promising preparation technique that has advantages in effectively saving reaction time, hastening the crystallization process, and producing phase-pure products of PCP materials in high yield and large scale, although its application in the crystal growth of large single crystals suitable for single-crystal diffraction has been scarcely reported.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the conventional heating solvothermal method, which requires a long time (typically half to several days) and high electric power (over a thousand Watts), microwave-assisted heating is a greener approach to synthesize materials in a shorter time (several minutes to hours) and with lower power consumption (hundreds of Watts) as a consequence of directly and uniformly heating the contents. Consequently, it emerges as a feasible approach in organic synthesis, inorganic hybrid materials and for nanoscale particle preparations. One can reasonably expect that microwave-assisted solvothermal synthesis (MASS) is a promising preparation technique that has advantages in effectively saving reaction time, hastening the crystallization process, and producing phase-pure products of PCP materials in high yield and large scale, although its application in the crystal growth of large single crystals suitable for single-crystal diffraction has been scarcely reported.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the synthesis and characterization of a porous metal-carboxylate framework [Cu2(oba)2(DMF)2]·5.25DMF (MCF-23, H2oba = 4,4′-oxydibenzoic acid). Since conventional solvothermal reactions did not produce a satisfactory product, we have developed a multistep MASS approach to efficiently synthesize phase-pure MCF-23 in high yield. The dynamic structural transformation of MCF-23 upon release and reabsorption of guest molecules has also been studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and gas adsorption studies.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report the synthesis and characterization of a porous metal-carboxylate framework [Cu2(oba)2(DMF)2]⋅5.25DMF (MCF-23, H2oba = 4,4'-oxydibenzoic acid). Since conventional solvothermal reactions did not produce a satisfactory product, we have developed a multistep MASS approach to efficiently synthesize phase-pure MCF-23 in high yield. The dynamic structural transformation of MCF-23 upon release and reabsorption of guest molecules has also been studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and gas adsorption studies.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H and N elemental analysis was carried out on a Vario EL elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using KBr pellets. The scanning electron micrographs (SEM) were obtained using a Quanta 400 thermal FE environment scanning electron microscope. TGA was performed on a NETZSCH TG 209 F3 thermogravimetric analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. The PXRD data were collected on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The adsorption isotherms of N2 and CO2 were measured respectively at 77 and 195 K using a BEL-max adsorption instrument (BEL Japan).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All chemicals were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H and N elemental analysis was carried out on a Vario EL elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using KBr pellets. The scanning electron micrographs (SEM) were obtained using a Quanta 400 thermal FE environment scanning electron microscope. TGA was performed on a NETZSCH TG 209 F3 thermogravimetric analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1. The PXRD data were collected on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The adsorption isotherms of N2 and CO2 were measured respectively at 77 and 195 K using a BEL-max adsorption instrument (BEL Japan).

elements.content: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and the mixture was then sealed in a 50-mL Teflon-lined reactor, which was heated to 160 °C and kept for 72 h. The autoclave was cooled over a period of 12 h at a rate of 10 °C h−1 to room temperature. Green block crystals with considerable brown impurities were obtained (ca. 50% ‘yield′ based on Cu and impurities not separated).
elements.clean_text:
Conventional Solvothermal Preparation of [Cu2(oba)2(DMF)2]⋅5.25DMF (MCF-23)

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and the mixture was then sealed in a 50-mL Teflon-lined reactor, which was heated to 160 °C and kept for 72 h. The autoclave was cooled over a period of 12 h at a rate of 10 °C h-1 to room temperature. Green block crystals with considerable brown impurities were obtained (ca. 50% ‘yield' based on Cu and impurities not separated).

elements.content: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor and kept for a specific time (1, 5, 15, 30 or 150 min). The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green microcrystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (60% yield based on Cu).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Step MASS Preparation of MCF-23

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor and kept for a specific time (1, 5, 15, 30 or 150 min). The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green microcrystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (60% yield based on Cu).

elements.content: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor. The reactor was heated to 80 °C and kept for 30 min, and then heated to 120 °C and kept for 30 min, and finally heated to 160 °C and kept for 1 h. The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green block crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (80% yield based on Cu). These crystals are stable in the mother liquid but easily lose guest molecules and effloresce into microcrystals in air. Anal. Calc. for the guest-free product (C28H16Cu2O10, M = 639.51): C, 52.59, H, 2.52; Found: C, 52.11; H, 2.43%. IR (KBr/cm−1): 539(w), 663(m), 777(m), 872(m), 1012(w), 1101(m), 1237(s), 1400(s), 1499(w), 1608(s), 1665(m), 2375(w) and 3431(m).
elements.clean_text:
Multistep MASS Preparation of MCF-23

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor. The reactor was heated to 80 °C and kept for 30 min, and then heated to 120 °C and kept for 30 min, and finally heated to 160 °C and kept for 1 h. The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green block crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (80% yield based on Cu). These crystals are stable in the mother liquid but easily lose guest molecules and effloresce into microcrystals in air. Anal. Calc. for the guest-free product (C28H16Cu2O10, M = 639.51): C, 52.59, H, 2.52; Found: C, 52.11; H, 2.43%. IR (KBr/cm-1): 539(w), 663(m), 777(m), 872(m), 1012(w), 1101(m), 1237(s), 1400(s), 1499(w), 1608(s), 1665(m), 2375(w) and 3431(m).

elements.content: A green block crystal (0.20 × 0.16 × 0.12 mm3) was sealed in a capillary with mother liquid for diffraction measurement on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. All intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects (SAINT), and empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied (SADABS). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with SHELXTL program package. Except those of DMF ligands, all non-hydrogen atoms of the framework were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The organic hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atom. The solvent molecules were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models; thus the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The final chemical formula was estimated from the SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA results. The R 1 value is 0.1007 before SQUEEZE was applied and the electron density is 819 electrons per cell which match that of the solvent molecules. Selected crystallographic data and structure determination parameters are given in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Analysis

A green block crystal (0.20 × 0.16 × 0.12 mm3) was sealed in a capillary with mother liquid for diffraction measurement on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. All intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects (SAINT), and empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied (SADABS). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with SHELXTL program package. Except those of DMF ligands, all non-hydrogen atoms of the framework were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The organic hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atom. The solvent molecules were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models; thus the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The final chemical formula was estimated from the SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA results. The R 1 value is 0.1007 before SQUEEZE was applied and the electron density is 819 electrons per cell which match that of the solvent molecules. Selected crystallographic data and structure determination parameters are given in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles in .

elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for MCF-23 empirical formula C44.25H54.25Cu2N5.25O15.25 formula weight 1030.77 T/K 293(2) crystal size/mm 0.20 × 0.16 × 0.12 cryst syst orthorhombic space group Pnna a/Å 23.567(5) b/Å 15.899(3) c/Å 17.476(4) V/Å3 6548(2) Z 4 D c/g·cm−3 0.797 μ/mm−1 0.684 R 1 (I > 2σ) 0.0716 wR 2 (all data) 0.1784 goodness-of fit on F 2 0.998 Δρmin/max (e/Å3) 1.493/−0.768

R 1 = ∑∥F o| − |F c∥/∑|F o|. wR 2 = [∑w(F o 2 − F c 2)2/∑w(F o 2)2]1/2.

The crystal structure of MCF-23 consists of two-dimensional (2-D) frameworks constructed by connections of the well-known paddle-wheel dinuclear Cu2(COO)4 secondary building units (SBUs) with the oxydiphenyl spacers in a (4,4) topology (Figure ). As a ditopic linker, the V-shape oba with an ether-oxygen site (COC = 121.6(6)°) and two noncoplanar phenyl rings (torsion angle 65.1°) is very flexible in helping the packing of layers in the solid state. In fact, such layers are undulated and are distinct from the planar layers of [Cu2(DBC)2] and [Zn2(DBC)2(H2O)2]·2DMF, leading to very strong off-set π-π stacking (interplanar distance 3.2 Å) of the oba phenyl groups between adjacent layers. Consequently, the adjacent layers are stacked in an ABAB fashion into a robust supramolecular 3-D structure, featuring potential porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The crystal structure of MCF-23 consists of two-dimensional (2-D) frameworks constructed by connections of the well-known paddle-wheel dinuclear Cu2(COO)4 secondary building units (SBUs) with the oxydiphenyl spacers in a (4,4) topology (Figure ). As a ditopic linker, the V-shape oba with an ether-oxygen site (COC = 121.6(6)°) and two noncoplanar phenyl rings (torsion angle 65.1°) is very flexible in helping the packing of layers in the solid state. In fact, such layers are undulated and are distinct from the planar layers of [Cu2(DBC)2] and [Zn2(DBC)2(H2O)2]⋅2DMF, leading to very strong off-set π-π stacking (interplanar distance 3.2 Å) of the oba phenyl groups between adjacent layers. Consequently, the adjacent layers are stacked in an ABAB fashion into a robust supramolecular 3-D structure, featuring potential porosity.

elements.content: Coordination environment of the dinuclear Cu(II) unit (a), (4 × 4) sheet (b), ABA layer stacking featuring offset face-to-face π−π stacking interactions of oba phenyl groups (c) in MCF-23.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environment of the dinuclear Cu(II) unit (a), (4 × 4) sheet (b), ABA layer stacking featuring offset face-to-face π-π stacking interactions of oba phenyl groups (c) in MCF-23.

elements.content: When the terminal DMF ligands of dinuclear SBUs are ignored, the supramolecular structure of MCF-23 contains 3-D channels. As shown in Figure , MCF-23 exhibits nanoscale channels running along the b-axis (12 × 9 Å2) (van der Waals radii included), which is slightly smaller than the cavity size of an individual layer because of the slight displacement between adjacent layers. Viewed along (111) and (01̅1) directions, there are elliptic and hourglass-shaped channels, which are 6.8 × 5.5 Å2 and 6.8 × 4.4 Å2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: When the terminal DMF ligands of dinuclear SBUs are ignored, the supramolecular structure of MCF-23 contains 3-D channels. As shown in Figure , MCF-23 exhibits nanoscale channels running along the b-axis (12 × 9 Å2) (van der Waals radii included), which is slightly smaller than the cavity size of an individual layer because of the slight displacement between adjacent layers. Viewed along (111) and (01̅1) directions, there are elliptic and hourglass-shaped channels, which are 6.8 × 5.5 Å2 and 6.8 × 4.4 Å2, respectively.

elements.content: Viewing the channels along the b-axis (a), (111) direction (b), and (01̅1) direction (c).
elements.clean_text: 2  Viewing the channels along the b-axis (a), (111) direction (b), and (01̅1) direction (c).

elements.content: MCF-23 was initially synthesized by a conventional solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2 and H2oba with DMF as solvent, which is dissimilar to our previous [Cu(oba)(dmso)] (MCF-21) prepared by similar reactants in a different solvent DMSO. However, concomitant impurity was always observed in the products, and it is very difficult to isolate the phase-pure product because the impurity is wrapped within the crystals. Thus, an alternative approach for the phase-pure product is necessary.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

MCF-23 was initially synthesized by a conventional solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2 and H2oba with DMF as solvent, which is dissimilar to our previous [Cu(oba)(dmso)] (MCF-21) prepared by similar reactants in a different solvent DMSO. However, concomitant impurity was always observed in the products, and it is very difficult to isolate the phase-pure product because the impurity is wrapped within the crystals. Thus, an alternative approach for the phase-pure product is necessary.

elements.content: When the single-step MASS method was applied to prepare MCF-23 by directly heating to 160 °C and incubating for 1 min, a crystalline product with an average size ca. 2 μm was obtained. However, when the incubation time was increased to 30 min, the average crystal size was not significantly increased. When the time was extended up to 150 min, the crystal size slightly increased (Figure ), while the yields in all trials were almost the same at ca. 60%. These results demonstrate that single-step MASS is difficult to generate single crystals large enough for X-ray single-crystal diffraction, even although the PXRD reveals a longer reaction time could lead to a higher degree of crystallinity (see ).
elements.clean_text: When the single-step MASS method was applied to prepare MCF-23 by directly heating to 160 °C and incubating for 1 min, a crystalline product with an average size ca. 2 μm was obtained. However, when the incubation time was increased to 30 min, the average crystal size was not significantly increased. When the time was extended up to 150 min, the crystal size slightly increased (Figure ), while the yields in all trials were almost the same at ca. 60%. These results demonstrate that single-step MASS is difficult to generate single crystals large enough for X-ray single-crystal diffraction, even although the PXRD reveals a longer reaction time could lead to a higher degree of crystallinity (see ).

elements.content: SEM images of MCF-23 synthesized via single-step MASS: (a) 1 min, (b) 5 min, (c) 10 min, (d) 30 min, (e) 150 min at 160 °C, and (f) photo of single crystals synthesized via multistep MASS.
elements.clean_text: 3  SEM images of MCF-23 synthesized via single-step MASS: (a) 1 min, (b) 5 min, (c) 10 min, (d) 30 min, (e) 150 min at 160 °C, and (f) photo of single crystals synthesized via multistep MASS.

elements.content: Although the crystals of micron size are appropriate for practical applications as porous materials, a larger size crystal is indispensable to explore single-crystal diffraction, which is important for discovering new PCPs. Therefore, we employed a multistep MASS approach with a stepwise warming technique, and succeeded in generating crystals with an average size of ca. 50 μm along with a few single crystals of size ca. 0.2 mm (see Figure f). The result implies that multistep MASS may be a new efficient approach for the growth of large single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis on a common diffractometer. Moreover, the as-synthesized product was phase-pure in a high yield of 80%, and no further purification is necessary. Actually, the PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized MCF-23 via single- or multistep MASS matched well with the simulated one, while that synthesized via conventional solvothermal method (see Figure d) matched very poorly owing to considerable impurities (the product contain MCF-23, as its crystals can be selected for single-crystal X-ray analysis).
elements.clean_text: Although the crystals of micron size are appropriate for practical applications as porous materials, a larger size crystal is indispensable to explore single-crystal diffraction, which is important for discovering new PCPs. Therefore, we employed a multistep MASS approach with a stepwise warming technique, and succeeded in generating crystals with an average size of ca. 50 μm along with a few single crystals of size ca. 0.2 mm (see Figure f). The result implies that multistep MASS may be a new efficient approach for the growth of large single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis on a common diffractometer. Moreover, the as-synthesized product was phase-pure in a high yield of 80%, and no further purification is necessary. Actually, the PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized MCF-23 via single- or multistep MASS matched well with the simulated one, while that synthesized via conventional solvothermal method (see Figure d) matched very poorly owing to considerable impurities (the product contain MCF-23, as its crystals can be selected for single-crystal X-ray analysis).

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of MCF-23 by different synthesis methods: (a) simulated; (b) multistep MASS; (c) single-step MASS; (d) conventional solvothermal.
elements.clean_text: 4  The PXRD patterns of MCF-23 by different synthesis methods: (a) simulated; (b) multistep MASS; (c) single-step MASS; (d) conventional solvothermal.

elements.content: The cavities of MCF-23 are occupied by 5.25 solvent DMF molecules per dinuclear unit, as estimated by SQUEEZE and TGA. The TGA curve (Figure ) of the as-synthesized MCF-23 shows a two-step loss below 250 °C. The first and gradual weight loss occurred between 30 and 100 °C, which corresponds to partial removal of the lattice solvents, while the second weight loss between 100 and 200 °C is attributed to the removal of the remaining lattice and ligated DMF molecules. The total weight loss 45.1% corresponds to 5.25 solvent and 2 ligated DMF molecules (calc. 45.3%).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Structural Dynamics

The cavities of MCF-23 are occupied by 5.25 solvent DMF molecules per dinuclear unit, as estimated by SQUEEZE and TGA. The TGA curve (Figure ) of the as-synthesized MCF-23 shows a two-step loss below 250 °C. The first and gradual weight loss occurred between 30 and 100 °C, which corresponds to partial removal of the lattice solvents, while the second weight loss between 100 and 200 °C is attributed to the removal of the remaining lattice and ligated DMF molecules. The total weight loss 45.1% corresponds to 5.25 solvent and 2 ligated DMF molecules (calc. 45.3%).

elements.content: The TGA curves of the as-synthesized (straight) and guest-free (dash) samples.
elements.clean_text: 5  The TGA curves of the as-synthesized (straight) and guest-free (dash) samples.

elements.content: A reversible structural transformation is observed by PXRD from the as-synthesized MCF-23 to the guest-free phase (denoted as MCF-23a), accompanied with DMF desorption/readsorption. By heating the as-synthesized sample up to 180 °C under vacuum (<10−2 Pa), the PXRD pattern of MCF-23 was changed into a new guest-free phase, or MCF-23a (). When the microcrystals of MCF-23a was treated in DMF vapor for one day, the PXRD pattern of MCF-23 was restored (), although the intensities were somewhat weakened. The reversible structural transformation from MCF-23 to guest-free MCF-23a demonstrated that MCF-23 behaves as a dynamic PCP.
elements.clean_text: A reversible structural transformation is observed by PXRD from the as-synthesized MCF-23 to the guest-free phase (denoted as MCF-23a), accompanied with DMF desorption/readsorption. By heating the as-synthesized sample up to 180 °C under vacuum (<10-2 Pa), the PXRD pattern of MCF-23 was changed into a new guest-free phase, or MCF-23a (). When the microcrystals of MCF-23a was treated in DMF vapor for one day, the PXRD pattern of MCF-23 was restored (), although the intensities were somewhat weakened. The reversible structural transformation from MCF-23 to guest-free MCF-23a demonstrated that MCF-23 behaves as a dynamic PCP.

elements.content: To verify the porosity of guest-free phase MCF-23a, gas sorption isotherms were measured with N2 and CO2. Prior to gas sorption experiments, the guest solvent molecules of MCF-23 were removed by thermal activation at 180 °C under vacuum over 20 h. MCF-23a adsorbs N2 gas in a two-step manner (Figure , inset), which may possibly be ascribed to the sliding of layers. Similar dynamic microporous 2D or interpenetrated 3D materials have scarcely been reported so far. A plateau with N2 uptake of ca. 35 mL·g−1 is observed below P/P o < 0.01. After that, the sorption sharply increases to reach saturation. There is no significant hysteresis between sorption and desorption traces. With an approximation based on a monolayer condensation of adsorbed N2 molecules on a uniform surface, the Langmuir surface area and the pore volume, estimated by applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich equations, are 580 m2·g−1 and 0.21 cm3·g−1, respectively. A plot of pore size distribution based on the Horvath−Kawazoe (HK) model indicates that the pore diameter of MCF-23a is ca. 9.7 Å (see ), which is virtually consistent with the X-ray data for MCF-23.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

To verify the porosity of guest-free phase MCF-23a, gas sorption isotherms were measured with N2 and CO2. Prior to gas sorption experiments, the guest solvent molecules of MCF-23 were removed by thermal activation at 180 °C under vacuum over 20 h. MCF-23a adsorbs N2 gas in a two-step manner (Figure , inset), which may possibly be ascribed to the sliding of layers. Similar dynamic microporous 2D or interpenetrated 3D materials have scarcely been reported so far. A plateau with N2 uptake of ca. 35 mL⋅g-1 is observed below P/P o < 0.01. After that, the sorption sharply increases to reach saturation. There is no significant hysteresis between sorption and desorption traces. With an approximation based on a monolayer condensation of adsorbed N2 molecules on a uniform surface, the Langmuir surface area and the pore volume, estimated by applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich equations, are 580 m2⋅g-1 and 0.21 cm3⋅g-1, respectively. A plot of pore size distribution based on the Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) model indicates that the pore diameter of MCF-23a is ca. 9.7 Å (see ), which is virtually consistent with the X-ray data for MCF-23.

elements.content: The N2 sorption isotherms of MCF-23a (inset shows the lower P/P o region).
elements.clean_text: 6  The N2 sorption isotherms of MCF-23a (inset shows the lower P/P o region).

elements.content: A similar two-step sorption phenomenon was also observed in the case of the CO2 isotherm at 195 K (Figure , inset shows the lower P/P o region). At low pressure, the adsorption amount of CO2 gradually increases to ca. 35 mL·g−1 until P/P o = 0.04, and then sharply increases at higher pressure regions to reach saturation. The coincident initial uptakes of N2 and CO2 at the first step indicate that the guest free MCF-23a contains relative small pores comparable to the sizes of the guests. On the other hand, after structural transformation, the relative large channels can accommodate more molecules of the smaller guests (N2 16.2 Å2, CO2 21.0 Å2). The different gate-opening pressures of N2 and CO2 should also be attributed to the size effect.
elements.clean_text: A similar two-step sorption phenomenon was also observed in the case of the CO2 isotherm at 195 K (Figure , inset shows the lower P/P o region). At low pressure, the adsorption amount of CO2 gradually increases to ca. 35 mL⋅g-1 until P/P o = 0.04, and then sharply increases at higher pressure regions to reach saturation. The coincident initial uptakes of N2 and CO2 at the first step indicate that the guest free MCF-23a contains relative small pores comparable to the sizes of the guests. On the other hand, after structural transformation, the relative large channels can accommodate more molecules of the smaller guests (N2 16.2 Å2, CO2 21.0 Å2). The different gate-opening pressures of N2 and CO2 should also be attributed to the size effect.

elements.content: The CO2 sorption isotherms of MCF-23a (inset shows the lower P/P o region).
elements.clean_text: 7  The CO2 sorption isotherms of MCF-23a (inset shows the lower P/P o region).

elements.content: In this work, we have successfully synthesized a new porous metal-carboxylate framework. This porous material can be satisfactorily synthesized by MASS methods, which requires short reaction time and provides good phase purity. Also importantly, the multistep MASS procedure is able to produce larger single crystals for single-crystal X-ray analysis. In contrast, the product obtained by the conventional solvothermal method was not phase-pure. Meanwhile, this new metal carboxylate framework features a dynamic structural transformation between the guest-loaded MCF-23 and the guest-free MCF-23a. Stepwise sorption behaviors for both dinitrogen and carbon dioxide also imply a gate-opening effect for guest pressure response of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, we have successfully synthesized a new porous metal-carboxylate framework. This porous material can be satisfactorily synthesized by MASS methods, which requires short reaction time and provides good phase purity. Also importantly, the multistep MASS procedure is able to produce larger single crystals for single-crystal X-ray analysis. In contrast, the product obtained by the conventional solvothermal method was not phase-pure. Meanwhile, this new metal carboxylate framework features a dynamic structural transformation between the guest-loaded MCF-23 and the guest-free MCF-23a. Stepwise sorption behaviors for both dinitrogen and carbon dioxide also imply a gate-opening effect for guest pressure response of the framework.

elements.content: Selected bond lengths and bond angles, X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, PXRD patterns of the samples obtained in different conditions, the distribution curve of pore size and gas sorption isotherms in a logarithmic plot for MCF-23a. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Selected bond lengths and bond angles, X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, PXRD patterns of the samples obtained in different conditions, the distribution curve of pore size and gas sorption isotherms in a logarithmic plot for MCF-23a. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and the mixture was then sealed in a 50-mL Teflon-lined reactor, which was heated to 160 °C and kept for 72 h. The autoclave was cooled over a period of 12 h at a rate of 10 °C h−1 to room temperature. Green block crystals with considerable brown impurities were obtained (ca. 50% ‘yield′ based on Cu and impurities not separated).

Single-Step MASS Preparation of MCF-23

Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor and kept for a specific time (1, 5, 15, 30 or 150 min). The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green microcrystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (60% yield based on Cu).

Multistep MASS Preparation of MCF-23

Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor. The reactor was heated to 80 °C and kept for 30 min, and then heated to 120 °C and kept for 30 min, and finally heated to 160 °C and kept for 1 h. The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green block crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (80% yield based on Cu). These crystals are stable in the mother liquid but easily lose guest molecules and effloresce into microcrystals in air. Anal. Calc. for the guest-free product (C28H16Cu2O10, M = 639.51): C, 52.59, H, 2.52; Found: C, 52.11; H, 2.43%. IR (KBr/cm−1): 539(w), 663(m), 777(m), 872(m), 1012(w), 1101(m), 1237(s), 1400(s), 1499(w), 1608(s), 1665(m), 2375(w) and 3431(m).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Conventional Solvothermal Preparation of [Cu2(oba)2(DMF)2]⋅5.25DMF (MCF-23)

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and the mixture was then sealed in a 50-mL Teflon-lined reactor, which was heated to 160 °C and kept for 72 h. The autoclave was cooled over a period of 12 h at a rate of 10 °C h-1 to room temperature. Green block crystals with considerable brown impurities were obtained (ca. 50% ‘yield' based on Cu and impurities not separated).

Single-Step MASS Preparation of MCF-23

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor and kept for a specific time (1, 5, 15, 30 or 150 min). The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green microcrystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (60% yield based on Cu).

Multistep MASS Preparation of MCF-23

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol) and H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, and then sealed in a microwave- specified 60-mL Teflon reactor. The reactor was heated to 80 °C and kept for 30 min, and then heated to 120 °C and kept for 30 min, and finally heated to 160 °C and kept for 1 h. The reactor was cooled to room temperature in 2 h. Green block crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF, and dried in air (80% yield based on Cu). These crystals are stable in the mother liquid but easily lose guest molecules and effloresce into microcrystals in air. Anal. Calc. for the guest-free product (C28H16Cu2O10, M = 639.51): C, 52.59, H, 2.52; Found: C, 52.11; H, 2.43%. IR (KBr/cm-1): 539(w), 663(m), 777(m), 872(m), 1012(w), 1101(m), 1237(s), 1400(s), 1499(w), 1608(s), 1665(m), 2375(w) and 3431(m).

cln_elements.content:
When the terminal DMF ligands of dinuclear SBUs are ignored, the supramolecular structure of MCF-23 contains 3-D channels. As shown in Figure , MCF-23 exhibits nanoscale channels running along the b-axis (12 × 9 Å2) (van der Waals radii included), which is slightly smaller than the cavity size of an individual layer because of the slight displacement between adjacent layers. Viewed along (111) and (01̅1) directions, there are elliptic and hourglass-shaped channels, which are 6.8 × 5.5 Å2 and 6.8 × 4.4 Å2, respectively.

Thermal Stability and Structural Dynamics

The cavities of MCF-23 are occupied by 5.25 solvent DMF molecules per dinuclear unit, as estimated by SQUEEZE and TGA. The TGA curve (Figure ) of the as-synthesized MCF-23 shows a two-step loss below 250 °C. The first and gradual weight loss occurred between 30 and 100 °C, which corresponds to partial removal of the lattice solvents, while the second weight loss between 100 and 200 °C is attributed to the removal of the remaining lattice and ligated DMF molecules. The total weight loss 45.1% corresponds to 5.25 solvent and 2 ligated DMF molecules (calc. 45.3%).

Gas Sorption Properties

To verify the porosity of guest-free phase MCF-23a, gas sorption isotherms were measured with N2 and CO2. Prior to gas sorption experiments, the guest solvent molecules of MCF-23 were removed by thermal activation at 180 °C under vacuum over 20 h. MCF-23a adsorbs N2 gas in a two-step manner (Figure , inset), which may possibly be ascribed to the sliding of layers. Similar dynamic microporous 2D or interpenetrated 3D materials have scarcely been reported so far. A plateau with N2 uptake of ca. 35 mL·g−1 is observed below P/P o < 0.01. After that, the sorption sharply increases to reach saturation. There is no significant hysteresis between sorption and desorption traces. With an approximation based on a monolayer condensation of adsorbed N2 molecules on a uniform surface, the Langmuir surface area and the pore volume, estimated by applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich equations, are 580 m2·g−1 and 0.21 cm3·g−1, respectively. A plot of pore size distribution based on the Horvath−Kawazoe (HK) model indicates that the pore diameter of MCF-23a is ca. 9.7 Å (see ), which is virtually consistent with the X-ray data for MCF-23.

A similar two-step sorption phenomenon was also observed in the case of the CO2 isotherm at 195 K (Figure , inset shows the lower P/P o region). At low pressure, the adsorption amount of CO2 gradually increases to ca. 35 mL·g−1 until P/P o = 0.04, and then sharply increases at higher pressure regions to reach saturation. The coincident initial uptakes of N2 and CO2 at the first step indicate that the guest free MCF-23a contains relative small pores comparable to the sizes of the guests. On the other hand, after structural transformation, the relative large channels can accommodate more molecules of the smaller guests (N2 16.2 Å2, CO2 21.0 Å2). The different gate-opening pressures of N2 and CO2 should also be attributed to the size effect.

Viewed along (111) and (01̅1) directions, there are elliptic and hourglass-shaped channels, which are 6.8 × 5.5 Å2 and 6.8 × 4.4 Å2, respectively.

The cavities of MCF-23 are occupied by 5.25 solvent DMF molecules per dinuclear unit, as estimated by SQUEEZE and TGA. The TGA curve (Figure ) of the as-synthesized MCF-23 shows a two-step loss below 250 °C. The first and gradual weight loss occurred between 30 and 100 °C, which corresponds to partial removal of the lattice solvents, while the second weight loss between 100 and 200 °C is attributed to the removal of the remaining lattice and ligated DMF molecules. The total weight loss 45.1% corresponds to 5.25 solvent and 2 ligated DMF molecules (calc. 45.3%).

To verify the porosity of guest-free phase MCF-23a, gas sorption isotherms were measured with N2 and CO2. Prior to gas sorption experiments, the guest solvent molecules of MCF-23 were removed by thermal activation at 180 °C under vacuum over 20 h. MCF-23a adsorbs N2 gas in a two-step manner (Figure , inset), which may possibly be ascribed to the sliding of layers. After that, the sorption sharply increases to reach saturation. There is no significant hysteresis between sorption and desorption traces. A similar two-step sorption phenomenon was also observed in the case of the CO2 isotherm at 195 K (Figure , inset shows the lower P/P o region). On the other hand, after structural transformation, the relative large channels can accommodate more molecules of the smaller guests (N2 16.2 Å2, CO2 21.0 Å2). The different gate-opening pressures of N2 and CO2 should also be attributed to the size effect.

pore diameter.condition: based on the Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) model, consistent with X-ray data

decomposition temperature.type: partial removal of the lattice solvents
removal of the remaining lattice and ligated DMF molecules

surface area.condition: estimated by applying the Langmuir equation

pore volume.condition: estimated by applying the Dubinin-Raduskhvich equation

gas adsorption.condition: initial uptake, two-step adsorption, no significant hysteresis
initial uptake, two-step adsorption, indicates small pores comparable to the sizes of the guests

metadata.title:
Microwave-Assisted Solvothermal Synthesis of a Dynamic Porous Metal-Carboxylate Framework
Dynamic Porous Metal-Carboxylate Framework
